diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A type of blood cancer that causes the bone marrow to make too many red blood cells. These excess cells thicken the blood, slowing its flow, which may cause complications such as blood clots.

diagnoses.name: Secondary Polycythemia
diagnoses.description: Occurs due to underlying conditions like chronic hypoxia or tumors producing erythropoietin, leading to increased red blood cell production.

diagnoses.name: Cardiac Arrhythmia
diagnoses.description: An irregular heartbeat that can cause palpitations. Conditions such as atrial fibrillation or tachycardia could be underlying causes.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.description: Although not directly linked, an underlying anemic condition might indirectly associate with the symptom of palpitations due to the heart working harder to circulate oxygen.

diagnoses.name: Bacterial Vaginosis
diagnoses.description: A condition in women where the balance of bacteria in the vagina is disturbed, leading to symptoms such as discharge, odor, and irritation, potentially correlating with terms like vaginitis.

diagnoses.name: Candidiasis
diagnoses.description: A fungal infection caused by yeasts that belong to the genus Candida. Symptoms include itching, redness, and discharge, fitting the description of vaginitis.

diagnoses.name: Constitutional Delay of Growth and Puberty
diagnoses.description: A temporary delay in physical development and pubertal growth relative to peers, fitting the described symptom of delayed puberty.

diagnoses.name: Hypogonadotropic Hypogonadism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the gonads produce little or no hormones. It is a potential cause for delayed puberty.

diagnoses.name: Otitis Externa
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the outer ear and ear canal. It aligns with the named condition and can be associated with infectious, allergic, or inflammatory causes.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions affecting thyroid function can indirectly lead to symptoms like palpitations or delayed puberty due to hormonal imbalances.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.reason: This autoimmune disease can cause symptoms like muscle pain, rashes, kidney dysfunction, and can also lead to aneurysms due to vascular damage.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.reason: Vasculitis, inflammation of the blood vessels, can cause muscle pain, rashes, and aneurysms, and may also affect kidney function.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.reason: Primarily characterized by muscle pain, it can coexist with various systemic diseases including those affecting the kidneys, though it doesn't directly cause kidney disease or aneurysms.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.reason: While primarily a kidney condition, it can cause muscle pain and is associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular issues like aneurysms. Specific rashes and skin changes can occur due to toxin accumulation.

diagnoses.name: Polyarteritis Nodosa
diagnoses.reason: This form of vasculitis can lead to kidney dysfunction, muscle pain, and aneurysms, with some patients also developing skin rashes.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.reason: A disease causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body, leading to symptoms such as mouth and genital ulcers, rashes, and potentially affecting the kidneys and causing aneurysms.

diagnoses.name: Marfan Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: A genetic disorder affecting connective tissue, causing symptoms that can include muscle pain and aneurysms, with potential involvement of the skin and kidneys.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: An autoimmune disease primarily affecting the eyes and mouth (dryness), it can also lead to muscle pain and has been associated with kidney disease as well as skin rashes.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.reason: This condition shares symptoms with several autoimmune diseases including muscle pain, rashes, and potentially affecting kidney function and causing aneurysms.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma
diagnoses.reason: An autoimmune disease of the connective tissue causing skin tightening and rashes, it can also affect the muscles, cause kidney disease, and vascular issues like aneurysms.

diagnoses: Vitamin Deficiencies – Certain vitamin deficiencies (like B12, zinc, and others) can lead to dysgeusia and sensory neuropathies.
Diabetes Mellitus – Can cause dysgeusia, irritability, and sensory neuropathies as part of diabetic neuropathy.
Hypothyroidism – Can present with dyspepsia, irritability, and sensory neuropathies, along with other systemic symptoms.
Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD) – While more directly causing dyspepsia, it can also lead to dysgeusia.
Multiple Sclerosis (MS) – Might present with dysgeusia and sensory neuropathies, among other neurological symptoms.
Fibromyalgia – Especially given the presence of sensory neuropathies and irritability; dyspepsia might also be seen.
Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS) – Primarily would explain dyspepsia but can be part of a broader symptom complex when considered alongside other non-GI symptoms like irritability.
Heavy Metal Poisoning – Could explain dysgeusia and sensory neuropathies; certain metals like lead or mercury can cause these symptoms.
Endometriosis – Noted in the symptoms, can also be associated with irritability due to hormonal imbalances and with dyspepsia if lesions involve the gastrointestinal tract.
Autoimmune Diseases – Conditions like Sjogren's syndrome can cause dysgeusia due to dry mouth, and systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) can have wide-ranging effects including sensory neuropathies.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Hypersensitivity reaction, including allergic reactions and anaphylaxis
Delayed puberty due to hormonal imbalance

diagnoses.name: Endometriosis
diagnoses.description: A painful, chronic condition where tissue similar to the lining inside the uterus grows outside the uterus.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A group of diseases that result in too much sugar in the blood (high blood glucose). Hyperglycemia is a hallmark.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition that causes pain all over the body, which might relate to the chronic back pain and episodic weakness.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition. Weakness and chronic pain may be symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
diagnoses.description: A common disorder that affects the large intestine. Symptoms include cramping, abdominal pain, bloating, gas, and nausea.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder common among women of reproductive age. Women with PCOS may have insulin resistance, leading to hyperglycemia.

diagnoses.name: Spinal Stenosis
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the spinal canal narrows and compresses the spinal cord and nerves. This is commonly associated with chronic back pain.

diagnoses.name: Adrenal Insufficiency
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the adrenal glands do not produce adequate amounts of steroid hormones, potentially impacting glucose metabolism and causing weakness and fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition where stomach contents come back up into the esophagus resulting in either symptoms or complications. It can present with nausea.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. It can cause episodic weakness among other symptoms.

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's disease and Ulcerative Colitis)
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, Ulcerative Colitis)

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death, causing symptoms such as headache, weakness, and aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a minibar, a temporary blockage of blood flow to the brain, causing similar, but temporary, symptoms to a stroke.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache that is often preceded or accompanied by sensory warning signs such as flashes of light, blind spots, or tingling in the hand or face.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain, symptoms depend on the location, size, and rate of growth.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that affects the brain and spinal cord, leading to weakness, coordination and speech difficulties, and in some cases, headaches.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the brain, often due to infection, leading to headache, fever, confusion, and in severe cases, seizures.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the brain and spinal cord membranes, typically caused by an infection. Symptoms include headache, fever, and stiff neck.

diagnoses.name: Primary Progressive Aphasia
diagnoses.description: A form of cognitive impairment that involves a progressive loss of language function.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A focal infection in the brain often causing headache, fever, weakness, and in some cases, language disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Hemorrhagic Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when a weakened blood vessel ruptures and bleeds into the surrounding brain, symptoms include sudden headache, weakness, and difficulty speaking.

diagnoses: Metabolic Disorders (e.g., vitamin E or B12 deficiency)

diagnoses.description: A stroke happens when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or severely reduced, depriving brain tissue of oxygen and nutrients. Symptoms can include dysphagia, scotoma, aphasia, and dysarthria.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a potentially disabling disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). It can lead to a variety of symptoms, including changes in sensation, vision loss (scotoma), and difficulties with coordination and speech (dysarthria).
Also known as Lou Gehrig's disease, ALS affects nerve cells in the brain and the spinal cord, causing loss of muscle control. Patients may experience dysarthria and dysphagia.
A brain tumor can cause a wide range of neurological symptoms depending on its location, including hearing loss, aphasia, dysarthria, and visual disturbances.
This type of headache is distinguished by the presence of neurological symptoms — known as aura — which may include visual symptoms like scotoma, as well as speech disturbances.

Myasthenia gravis is characterized by weakness and rapid fatigue of any of the muscles under your voluntary control. It's caused by a breakdown in the normal communication between nerves and muscles, and can lead to difficulties in speech (dysarthria) and swallowing (dysphagia).
A benign tumor on the main nerve leading from the inner ear to the brain. Symptoms may include hearing loss and difficulties with balance.
Often called a 'mini-stroke', a TIA produces similar symptoms to a stroke, including aphasia and dysarthria, but usually lasts only a few minutes and causes no permanent damage.
Age-related hearing loss that gradually occurs in most individuals as they grow older. It can contribute to difficulties in understanding speech that might be misinterpreted as cognitive issues.

Temporal arteritis causes inflammation and damage to the blood vessels that supply blood to the head, neck, upper body, and arms. It can lead to sudden, permanent vision loss (a form of scotoma) and other symptoms.

diagnoses: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Viral infections (e.g., Parvovirus B19, Epstein-Barr virus)
Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA, formerly known as Wegener's Granulomatosis)
